718803f-a.title: Manhattan: Christopher Street - West Street
718803f-a.text:
(1)
173, 171, 169 Christopher Street, north side, between West and
Washington Streets. No. 171 is the one-story frame shed in the center
of the picture.
In front of No. 173 stands the New York Publio Library's
Circulation Department truck, which travels about the Bronx.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, three years later. The frame shed has been faced
with tin; and the Volmer automobile agenoy has moved away from
No. 169.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 115.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

716473f-a.title: Manhattan: Barrow Street - West Street
716473f-a.folder: Barrow Street & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724710f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Barrow Street
724710f-a.text:
West Street, east side, south from Barrow to Morton St's.,
showing the block extending to Washington St. more or less
cleared. Aoross the New York Central Railroad elevated road-
bed (west side) appear loft structures on the east side of
Washington Street. The 8 story building, No. 517-31 Washing-
ton St., is occupied by Bellas, Hess \& Co. This utilizes the
entire frontage from Barrow to Morton St's. At the S.E. corner
of the latter thoroughfare, is the 9 story loft, No. 611-15
Washington St. identified with the Medical Supply Dept. of the
U. S. Army.
724710f-a.folder: West Street & Barrow Street, Manhattan, NY

724947f-a.folder: West Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

724722f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Christopher Street
724722f-a.text:
(1)
West Street, center and east side, from Christopher Street to West
10th (formerly Amos) Street, opposite Piers 44 to 45, North River,
and eaat on the north side of Christopher Street towards Greenwich
Street. The spines in the background are those of St. Veronica's
Roman Catholic Church at 153-139 Christopher Street.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A portion of the same, showing prominently Nos. 391 to 393 (right to
left). No. 388, the 3-story brick, corner building and the adjoining
27structure have been demolished in this view. This row of buildings
replaced the Weehawken Market that was built here about 1830 on a portion
of the New York State Prison site. Weehawken Street (shown across vacant
lot) was cut through at tht time.
About 1937.
Hift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.
Nieg ~1942
724722f-a.folder: West Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

724716f-a.title: Manhattan: West Street - Christopher Street
724716f-a.text:
West Street, west side, north from and including the ferries
at Pier 44, North River, opposite Christopher Street. This view
was taken the year before the building of the first section of
the West Side Elevated Highway.
March 8, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
724716f-a.folder: West Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

724719f-b.title: Manhattan: West Street - Christopher Street
724719f-b.text:
(1)
West Street, east side, north from Christopher Street, showing a
clearance (N.E. corner), where Nos. 388 and 390 West Street stood.1
The old 2 112-story building,shown in a state of collapse, is No. ,291.
On the right appears the east side of Ueehawken Street, between Christ-
opher and West 10th Streets.
May 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
A limited view, showing a closer view of No. 591. A similar
building (frame) just north, is No. 393.
May 15, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPPODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same as view No. 1, showing however, a more extensive view
of the north side of Christopher Street (right), east from West Street,
across Weehawken Street.
May 15, 1937.
Sperr.  96 Ehrabbucioss.
724719f-b.folder: West Street & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY

724322f-a.title: Manhattan: Weehawken Street - Christopher Street
724322f-a.text:
Weehawken Street, west side, between Christopher and
West 10th Street, showing the rear of the building bear-
ing No. 393 West Street. This is popularly supposed to
be the oldest structure in Manhattan. It rests on the
site of the Weehawken Market, and which in turn succeeded
to a portion of the old State Prison of 1797-1829. For
further information, see, the New York Times of, Sunday,
August 22, 1937. a/co : V.yf.we N2(~ 7e. 1P, 1 720
About 1939
Alexandcr Alland, photo
NO REPRODUCTIONS
